gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In our Elasticsearch Exporter we support management of index lifecycles with ILM. OpenSearch provides a similar mechanic called ISM. In other to keep the exporters aligned and fully support OpenSearch we should add support for ISM to our OpenSearch Exporter.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Users should be able to configure ISM similar to how ILM works. The solution must support both OpenSearch 1.3.x and 2.8.x

This also should be documented in the [OpenSearch Exporter docs](https://docs.camunda.io/docs/next/self-managed/zeebe-deployment/exporters/opensearch-exporter/)!

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Not implementing this. Users could do it through the OpenSearch UI. It is less convenient and an extra burden on users. It would also mean we'd provide more feature in our Elasticsearch Exporter than our OpenSearch Exporter.

**Additional context**
N/A
title: Support Index State Management in OpenSearch exporter

gitHubText:
### Description

The Java client provides a `BroadcastSignalCommand` for broadcasting tenant-aware signals in Zeebe. These commands should support multi-tenancy by exposing an optional `tenantId` property/method.

The following error codes may be returned:
* PERMISSION_DENIED (code: 7) 
   * when a user attempts to broadcast a signal of a tenant they are not authorized for, when multi-tenancy is enabled.
* INVALID_ARGUMENT (code: 3)
   * For a provided tenant id, when multi-tenancy is disabled
   * For a missing tenant id, when multi-tenancy is enabled
   * For an invalid tenant id (i.e. doesn't match the pre-defined format), when multi-tenancy is enabled.
title: Java client supports multi-tenancy for BroadcastSignal RPC

gitHubText:
### Description

The Zeebe Go client should support multi-tenancy.

The following commands should provide a method to set a `tenantId`:
* `DeployResource`
* `CreateProcessInstance`
* `PublishMessage`
* `BroadcastSignal`
* `EvaluateDecision`

The following commands should provide a method to set `tenantIds`:
* `ActivateJobs`
title: Go client commands allow specifying a `tenantId` / `tenantIds` property

gitHubText:
**Description**

#6093 provides a backoff mechanism for the java client's job worker. When an error is received from the gateway by the job poller, the worker delays its next poll for available jobs. The go client should support the same functionality.

This functionality should be the same as the java client's. Including:
- a default exponential backoff mechanism with the same defaults: {maxDelay:5s, minDelay:50ms, backoffFactor:1.6, jitterFactor:0.1}
- the exponential backoff should be configurable
- users should be able to provide their own implementation of a backoff strategy
- backoff should only occur on errors received on the poll for available jobs

 Sijoma: Hey yall, I did a implementation for this for the go client. I'm a bit unsure in which cases the backoff should be applied though. 

Is it every time there is a ResourceExhausted? Or also when it fails to reopen the job polling stream? Is here: `clients/go/pkg/worker/jobPoller.go:95` the correct place?


 korthout: The backoff should be applied when the job poller fails to ask for jobs from the gateway. For example, in Java, [it backs off when any exception is thrown during the polling for jobs](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/069c17a74398d291b95d1c761357a457c62257ae/clients/java/src/main/java/io/zeebe/client/impl/worker/JobWorkerImpl.java#L136-L147). So that it actually controlled from the JobWorker, the poller is just used once in a while by the job worker.

This seems to happen differently in the go client, but the details are a bit unclear to me. Somewhere [around here](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/clients/go/pkg/worker/jobPoller.go#L77-L114) would be my guess. 

I think that this part is the [main loop](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/clients/go/pkg/worker/jobPoller.go#L47-L71) for the poller. It seems to:
- poll for jobs, and add them to the job queue
- determine if it if needs to poll again

So, what is needed is some way to backoff from polling when an error occurs during polling. There are [other errors](https://docs.camunda.io/docs/apis-clients/grpc/#technical-error-handling) than `RESOURCE_EXHAUSTED` that could occur during polling.
 Sijoma: Thanks for the info @korthout, indeed it looks a bit differently in the go client. I will put in a draft-pr :).
title: go-client: Job worker polling backoff mechanism

gitHubText:
When migrating a process instance:
- there may exist event subscriptions in the process instance
- there may be events that must be subscribed to in the target process

Migrating the existing event subscriptions is difficult, because they can exist on other partitions than the process instance, e.g. message subscription.

We can deal with this by unsubscribing each active element instance in the process instance **and** subscribing to new events in the target process for each migrated element instance.

title: Migrate task instances with recreated event subscriptions

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
To add support for authentication via [Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) and generic OpenID Connect](https://github.com/camunda/product-hub/issues/739) it is required to set the `scope` parameter in the token request, see [Microsoft Entra ID docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-client-creds-grant-flow#first-case-access-token-request-with-a-shared-secret). Currently the Zeebe java client does not support setting the `scope` parameter.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The Zeebe client supports setting the `scope` parameter in the token request (for example in https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/clients/java/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/client/impl/oauth/OAuthCredentialsProvider.java#L125)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Use Identity-sdk which supports creating auth tokens.

**Additional context**
- When using Microsoft Entra ID, the scope parameter has to contain the client api in a specific format, for example `scope=4393964b-2273-4b23-94fa-98c3d2396b1e/.default`
- The additional parameter has to also be integrated into [`spring-zeebe`](https://github.com/camunda-community-hub/spring-zeebe) since it is used by Connectors

 megglos: > The additional parameter has to also be integrated into [spring-zeebe](https://github.com/camunda-community-hub/spring-zeebe) since it is used by Connectors

@dlavrenuek from my understanding, having the env var support in the client which you added with https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/pull/15404 will be enough to make use of it in spring-zeebe, right?
 1nb0und: 1. Are we also considering adding the scope soon to other components as well (operate, optimize, etc) ?
2. If yes on above, will all components use the same scope, or different components will use its own scope?

 megglos: @1nb0und best reach out on the product-hub issue https://github.com/camunda/product-hub/issues/739 to the PM and engineering DRI
title: Allow setting `scope` parameter for OAuth2 authentication

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Camunda Identity now provides an `identity-spring-boot-starter` which, in turn, provides an `IdentityConfiguration` Spring bean.

The goal is to decouple the Identity configuration properties from the Zeebe configuration classes. The `identity-spring-boot-starter` should create an `IdentityConfiguration` Spring bean, which in turn can be used to configure the `identity-sdk` inside Zeebe. 

The outcome will be that Zeebe doesn't need to add new Identity configuration properties every time Identity adds them.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

- [x] The `IdentityInterceptor` class should create an `Identity` instance using an `IdentityConfiguration` instance ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/303b0d7bbc60440fee8baaf943ab020d49783d38/gateway/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/gateway/interceptors/impl/IdentityInterceptor.java#L37-L39)).
- [x] The `Gateway` class should pass an `IdentityConfiguration` instance to the `IdentityInterceptor` constructor ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/b3c3397f10b8e96d12af053ff72d616f80264dca/gateway/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/gateway/Gateway.java#L323-L328)).
- [x] The `StandaloneGateway` class should `Autowire` an `IdentityConfiguration` bean and pass it along to the `Gateway` constructor ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/44769129dbfbdee7b44889780215d20e395453f2/dist/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/gateway/StandaloneGateway.java#L101-L103)).
- [x] The `EmbeddedGatewayService` class should pass an `IdentityConfiguration` instance to the `Gateway` constructor ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/de669e90aa74a0330f6e17f07de0b14aa430a2cc/broker/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/broker/system/EmbeddedGatewayService.java#L36-L37)).
   - The `IdentityConfiguration` bean should be passed through the `StandaloneBroker` class ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/4c4e7d2404f00045e5ac3d033e007e30b063b14c/dist/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/broker/StandaloneBroker.java#L82)).
- [x] The `MultiTenancyOverIdentityIT` test should configure Identity using an `IdentityConfiguration` bean ([src](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/d98d04cbe6ab675c981aea808566264f8552d647/qa/integration-tests/src/test/java/io/camunda/zeebe/it/multitenancy/MultiTenancyOverIdentityIT.java#L210-L213)).


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
- None. Zeebe needs to integrate the `identity-spring-boot-starter` in order to decouple the Identity configuration properties from Zeebe.

**Additional context**
* https://github.com/camunda/product-hub/issues/1849
* https://github.com/camunda-cloud/identity/issues/2162
title: Configure `identity-sdk` through `identity-spring-boot-starter` in the Gateway

gitHubText:
Introduce a new `VariableIntent` `MIGRATED`.

Add an event applier that updates the following properties of a variable:

- `bpmnProcessId`: the BPMN ID of the target process definition
- `processDefinitionVersion`: the version of the target process definition
- `processDefinitionKey`: the key of the target process definition

In the `ProcessInstanceMigration` command processor, add:
- for each variable of a process instance:
  - append `Variable:MIGRATED` event
- for each child element instance of the process:
  - append `Variable:MIGRATED` event for each variable at that scope

Make sure to clear the variable's `value` when appending these events to avoid exceeding the result records batch size.

Add a test case that show that we can migrate a process instance, and use the variables in activated jobs and can update the variables with the Set Variables RPC.

**Alternatively**
Find a way to migrate all variables for a process instance in a single pass. I'm not sure this is possible.

**Out of scope**
Migrate all variables with a single event.

Blocked by:
- #15113 

 sdorokhova: Hi @korthout , I don't think that variable has `elementId` field. Is this a copy-paste error?
But variable has `scopeKey` field. Can it change?
 korthout: Good point @sdorokhova, I've removed the `elementId` from the list in the description.

The `scopeKey` won't change. Variables will stay existing at the same scope. We're not planning to move variables to different scopes. That might be needed when we make Sub Process hierarchy changes possible, but even then I doubt we'll move variables. If we change our mind on this for future iterations, we'll let you know in time.
title: Migrate task instances with variables

gitHubText:
Introduce a new `JobIntent` `MIGRATED`.

Add an event applier that updates the following properties of a job:

- `bpmnProcessId`: the BPMN ID of the target process definition
- `processDefinitionVersion`: the version of the target process definition
- `processDefinitionKey`: the key of the target process definition
- `elementId`: changes to the mapped element ID of the associated service task (note that the mapping may define the sourceElementId and the targetElementId as equivalent, in which case it stays the same)

In the `ProcessInstanceMigration` command processor, add:
- for each child instance of the process instance:
  - append `ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_MIGRATED` event
  - if this child is of type `SERVICE_TASK`, append `Job:MIGRATED` event

Add a test case that show that we can migrate a process instance, and can still use all job commands, e.g. activate, fail, throwError, yield, complete, etc.

Blocked by:
- https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/issues/15111
title: Migrate service task instances (including jobs)

gitHubText:
## Description

We need a new record for compensation events. It should be used to:
- Find completed activities with compensation handlers
- Keep track of the compensation handler state: ready for invocation, invoked  
- Find the compensation throw event that triggered a compensation handler

The compensation record may contain the following data:
- tenant id
- process instance key
- process definition key
- element id of activity with compensation handler
- flow scope element id of activity with compensation handler
- element id of compensation throw event
- element instance key of compensation throw event
- local variables of activity with compensation handler (i.e. snapshot data for compensation event subprocess)
 
The lifecycle of a compensation record may contain the following states:

```
CREATED -> TRIGGERED -> COMPLETED | DELETED
```

- CREATED: 
  - when an activity with a compensation boundary event is completed, or
  - when an embedded subprocess with a compensation event subprocess is completed
  - then add the subscription to the state 
- TRIGGERED: 
  - when the compensation throw event is activated
  - then set the element instance key and element id of the compensation throw event
  - and update the subscription in the state
- COMPLETED: 
  - when the compensation handler is completed
  - then remove the subscription from the state
- DELETED: 
  - when the process instance is completed or terminated
  - then remove the subscription from the state  

We should follow the development guide on how to create a new record [here](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/docs/developer_handbook.md#how-to-create-a-new-record).

 saig0: I created a separate issue for exporting these events: #15140. If possible, we can work on the exporters as a follow-up.
title: Introduce new compensation subscription record

gitHubText:
Add new Intent to the `JobIntent` class

- `UPDATE_TIMEOUT`
This command will look for the Job in the state and for it's deadline. If it can't find one of those it will return a `NOT_FOUND` rejection. Otherwise it will write the `TIMEOUT_UPDATED` event which will modify the deadline in the state.
- `TIMEOUT_UPDATED`
This event will update the `JOB_DEADLINES` ColumnFamily. Since the key of this ColumnFamily is deadline-jockey we can't just update the existing one. Instead we will need to remove the existing entry for this Job, and insert a new value. For this we must have access to the old deadline. This is stored in state and should available through the JobRecord.
title: Add Job Update Timeout intents

gitHubText:
## Description 

When we execute a BPMN process, we write events of the value type `ProcessInstance`. These events have a field `bpmnEventType`. The field is set for BPMN events with their respective type. 

To reflect the execution of compensation events, we need to introduce a new [event type](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/protocol/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/protocol/record/value/BpmnEventType.java) `COMPENSATION`. All events related to a BPMN compensation event should have the event type `COMPENSATION` (i.e. compensation intermediate throwing events, compensation end events, compensation boundary events, compensation start events).
title: The record for a compensation event has the correct event type

gitHubText:
## Description

In order to execute a process with compensation events, we need to deploy the process first. Currently, it is impossible to deploy a process with compensation event subprocesses because of validation rules.  

Adjust the validation rules to allow compensation start events within event subprocesses.

Additionally, we ensure the following restrictions:
- A compensation start event must be within an event subprocess.
- A compensation event subprocess must be within an embedded subprocess. The event subprocess is not allowed on the process level. 

![Screenshot from 2023-11-01 13-15-57](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/4305769/4ff1a5e7-600e-42f5-9918-b29d82f3c0e8)

requires #14939 
requires #14942
title: I can deploy a process with BPMN compensation event subprocesses

gitHubText:
## Description

In order to execute a process with compensation events, we need to deploy the process first. Currently, it is impossible to deploy a process with compensation events because of validation rules.  

Adjust the validation rules to allow the following BPMN elements:
- Compensation intermediate throwing event
- Compensation end event
- Compensation boundary event
- Activity with compensation marker (i.e. a compensation handler)

Additionally, we ensure the following restrictions:
- A compensation boundary event should have no outgoing sequence flows. The compensation handler is connected by an association. 
- A compensation handler should have no incoming and outgoing sequence flows.
- A compensation handler should have no boundary events.
- Only the following activities can have a compensation marker:
  - Service Tasks
  - User Tasks
  - Send Tasks
  - Script Tasks
  - Manual Tasks
  - Undefined Tasks
- A compensation intermediate throwing or end event should have no attribute `waitForCompletion` or `waitForCompletion` must be `true`. By default, the attribute is `true` (i.e. the throwing event waits until the compensation is complete).  

![Screenshot from 2023-11-01 12-43-10](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/4305769/1f69fed7-0dcd-48cd-a3ee-a441647c4886)


requires #14939
title: I can deploy a process with BPMN compensation events

gitHubText:
## Description

The BPMN model API supports compensation events already. But, creating a process via builder with compensation events is verbose and feels clunky. 

See the example here:

```java
Bpmn.createExecutableProcess("compensation-process")
            .startEvent()
            .userTask("A")
            .boundaryEvent()
            .compensateEventDefinition()
            .compensateEventDefinitionDone()
            .compensationStart()
            .userTask("undo-A")
            .compensationDone()
            .endEvent()
            .done();
```

![Screenshot from 2023-11-01 11-10-35](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/4305769/94e1f994-a3cd-4c4b-9045-01acd38e6ac5)

We will need the builder to create test cases for compensation events. Let's make the builder smoother for better test cases.

See the proposal based on other events. The final solution may look different. 

```java
Bpmn.createExecutableProcess("compensation-process")
        .startEvent()
        .userTask("A")
        .boundaryEvent()
        .compensation(c -> c.userTask("undo-A"))
        .moveToActivity("A")
        .endEvent()
        .done();

// or via nested lambda definition 
Bpmn.createExecutableProcess("compensation-process")
        .startEvent()
        .userTask("A")
        .boundaryEvent(
            "compensate",
            boundaryEvent -> boundaryEvent.compensation().userTask("undo-A"))
        .endEvent()
        .done();
```
title: I can model a process with compensation events via BPMN model API

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently we have Dependabot and Renovate in our repo, makes sense to only use one, and Renovate seems to cover all our use cases, unlike Dependabot (see https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/issues/13409).

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Change renovate.json to also cover the maven and docker updates. Remove the Dependabot tool for these (do we have other things being updated by Dependabot?).

The following command can be used to test renovate locally:
```
npx renovate --token=$GITHUB_TOKEN --schedule="" --require-config=ignored --dry-run=full camunda/zeebe 

```

Also helps to set the env var LOG_LEVEL=debug, so that the previous command produces more information.

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently Forms are received from the state without using any caching mechanism. Adding a caching for recently retrieved Forms will increase the performance of retrieval. We do a similar implementation for Decision and Process resources in their `DbState` classes as well.

Since deploying forms to Zeebe is a feature that is introduced in 8.3, there is no such requirement or problems with performance at the moment. Therefore, this issue is just an performance improvement at the moment.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add caching mechanism to DbFormState as already done for Decision and Process states.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The alternative is basically not using caching at all and that is already implemented.

**Additional context**
EPIC link: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/issues/12874
title: Use caching for Forms

gitHubText:
Zeebe 8.3.0 only supports multi-tenancy over Identity:

https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/5b23af53e0c3837abc11325a8a496ac37f793e4e/dist/src/main/config/broker.standalone.yaml.template#L108-L119

Users may want to use their own tenant provider. We want to make this available using [custom interceptors](https://docs.camunda.io/docs/next/self-managed/zeebe-deployment/zeebe-gateway/interceptors/).

According to [the decision made below](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/issues/14285#issuecomment-1851578839), the following tasks need to be completed:

### Tasks
- [x] Expand the `InterceptorUtil` class to provide the `AUTHORIZED_TENANTS_KEY` gRPC context key.
- [x] ~Extract the tenant-providing logic from the `IdentityInterceptor` into a new `IdentityTenantProvidingInterceptor`~
	1. ~This new interceptor is added only if `identity` is set as the `authentication.mode`, and `multiTenancy` is enabled (set to `true`).~
	2. Won't be done since the tenant-providing logic for Identity is closely tied to the Identity token, which is validated within the `IdentityInterceptor`. We would have to extract the token twice if we extract the tenant-providing logic.
- [x] Handling `tenantId` data:
	1. Only use the data provided by the `AUTHORIZED_TENANTS_KEY` gRPC Context key if multi-tenancy is enabled.
- [x] Tests
	1. Ensure that the existing tests that cover multi-tenancy over Identity pass
	2. Add IT tests to ensure that the Gateway uses the data provided by a custom tenant-providing interceptor when multi-tenancy is enabled.
	4. Add IT tests to ensure that the Gateway doesn't use the data provided by a custom tenant-providing interceptor when multi-tenancy is disabled.
	5. Add IT tests to ensure that a custom tenant-providing interceptor overrides the Identity tenant-providing interceptor when multi-tenancy is enabled.
- [x] https://github.com/camunda/camunda-docs/issues/3029:
       - Extend the [Interceptor docs](https://docs.camunda.io/docs/self-managed/zeebe-deployment/zeebe-gateway/interceptors/) with a section on *Implementing a tenant-providing interceptor*
       - Update the MultiTenancy docs for Zeebe to state that:
                - Multi-tenancy in Zeebe is independent from Identity, if Zeebe is used as a standalone product
                - If Zeebe is used as a standalone product, and multi-tenancy is enabled, users can implement a custom tenant-providing interceptor. A link to the Interceptor docs should be provided.
        - If the full Camunda 8 stack is used, then a custom tenant-providing interceptor can't be used, and Identity must be configured since other Camunda 8 components must use Identity.

 koevskinikola: Solution proposals:
1. Zeebe provides an `AbstractTenantProvidingInterceptor` class. 
    1. The class will implement the logic for adding the `tenantId` list to the gRPC context.
    2. Users will need to extend this class and implement the tenant-providing logic.
2. Zeebe provides a `TenantProvider` interface
    1. Zeebe uses a `TenantProvidingInterceptor` class in the Zeebe Gateway module. Implementations of the  `TenantProvider` interface are passed to this interceptor.
    2. Users will need to implement the `TenantProvider` interface
3. Zeebe extends the `InterceptorUtil` class to provide the `AUTHORIZED_TENANTS_KEY`, and documents (in a similar manner to the `QueryApi`) how to use it with the gRPC Context.
   1. Users may implement a "tenant-providing" interceptor as they see fit.
   2. We document this in the Zeebe Interceptors documentation.
 koevskinikola: Decision:
We use solution proposal [3] from [the list above](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/issues/14285#issuecomment-1847356998). Why:
* PRO: It provides the most flexibility for users. Users can implement their tenant-providing logic in any of their gRPC interceptors.
* PRO: It uses an existing Zeebe Interceptor mechanism (the `InterceptorUtil` class) to pass and extract data to/from interceptors.
* CON: Users may still provide a `tenantId` list using this mechanism when multi-tenancy is disabled, as we have no mechanism to prevent this within an interceptor.
   * However, we can control if the `tenantId` list is used or not inside the Gateway, depending if multi-tenancy is disabled or not.
   * The alternative to avoid this CON is to use approach [1] or [2]. However, we would need to re-implement a mechanism for instantiating externally provided classes (we have this with the `IdentityRepository`. Furthermore, these approaches are less flexible, as we would require users to either extend an abstract class or implement an interface inside their code.
title: Support general-usage tenant-providing interceptor for SM

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
As described in the issue #13410, we want to keep track of event types that triggered elements in Grafana. This is not possible without actually adding them to the job metric in the Engine.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Update `ProcessEngineMetrics` class to event types for `element_instance_events_total` metric. Then, update their usages for activated/completed/terminated element instances.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
As long as we want to show these metrics in Grafana, there is no a real alternative than keeping track of this metric in the Engine.

 korthout: Alternative solution, we can add another label to the [`element_instance_events_total` metric](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/engine/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/engine/metrics/ProcessEngineMetrics.java#L55-L61) to track `eventType`. (size: x-small)
 korthout: I'd propose to pick this up soon, so we can unblock #13410, which can help us troubleshoot issues faster and more easily.
title: Keep track of event types in the Engine

gitHubText:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In the past weeks, there was a support case where it reports that the Engine is lagging behind while process new records. The incident was resolved afterwards. The incident was caused by a timer catch event that keeps generating multiple new records, so that the thread pool was busy with generating new records.

While investigating in Grafana, the team were able to observe a catch event was taking the CPU time but cannot see which type of catch event was causing the issue. Therefore, cannot root cause the issue without looking at other log resources.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The type of events should be added to Grafana `General Overview -> Current Events` view. Every element instance should contains its own type

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternative way to achieve the same goal is to look at export logs which takes more time and less accessible than Grafana.

**Additional context**
It is more precise if we have activation, completion and termination information of catch events in the view.


 korthout: Marking this as `upcoming` as it can help us troubleshoot problems faster and more easily.

It is blocked by:
- #13433
title: Indicate the type of activated/completed/terminated catch events in Grafana

gitHubText:
In the `ClusterTopologyManager`, the `onGoingTopologyChangeOperation`flag  is only set back to `false` when an operation is applied.
It's not set to `false` if a change is cancelled or if an operation fails to initialize.
If there are new operations later, the manager will not start them because `onGoingTopologyChangeOperation` is still set to `true`.

Relates to #13642
title: Failed or cancelled topology change operations block further operations

gitHubText:
A broker can receive a new topology over gossip before the `TopologyInitializer` finished. At that point, the local topology is uninitialized and the received topology is persisted without merging.
This can result in a broker forgetting about already applied operations, something that we usually avoid by always persisting the local topology when changes are applied.

Normally, topology updates received via gossip should not overwrite an uninitialized topology. The only exception to this would be the `GossipInitializer`.

Relates to #13642
title: Topology received via gossip can bypass merge with locally persisted topology

gitHubText:
**Describe the bug**

After restoring from backup, some partitions encountered [following error](https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/query;cursorTimestamp=2023-09-26T11:26:03.072149905Z;endTime=2023-09-26T11:56:36.088Z;pinnedLogId=2023-09-26T11:26:01.585896295Z%2Fh1uykcs15coafgsq;query=logName:%22stdout%22%0Aresource.type%3D%22k8s_container%22%0Aresource.labels.container_name%3D%22zeebe%22%0Aresource.labels.namespace_name%3D%22eab43606-a898-467f-967f-21a757fc69b7-zeebe%22%0Aresource.labels.location%3D%22europe-west1%22%0Aresource.labels.project_id%3D%22camunda-saas-int-chaos%22%0Aresource.labels.cluster_name%3D%22worker-chaos-1%22%0Aresource.labels.pod_name%3D%22zeebe-1%22%0AjsonPayload.context.partitionId%3D%2226%22%0Atimestamp%3D%222023-09-26T11:26:01.585896295Z%22%0AinsertId%3D%22h1uykcs15coafgsq%22;startTime=2023-09-26T10:56:36.088Z;summaryFields=jsonPayload%252Fcontext%252FpartitionId,resource%252Flabels%252Fpod_name:false:32:beginning?project=camunda-saas-int-chaos).

```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Expected to delete index after 3982, but it is lower than the commit index 3983. Deleting committed entries can lead to inconsistencies and is prohibited.
	at io.atomix.raft.storage.log.RaftLog.deleteAfter(RaftLog.java:168) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.2.13.jar:8.2.13]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.tryToAppend(PassiveRole.java:565) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.2.13.jar:8.2.13]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.appendEntries(PassiveRole.java:511) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.2.13.jar:8.2.13]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.handleAppend(PassiveRole.java:367) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.2.13.jar:8.2.13]
```

What happened:

First Zeebe-1 votes for Zeebe-2 and Zeebe-2 becomes leader.
```
INFO 2023-09-26T11:25:57.870482436Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26}{role=FOLLOWER} - Accepted PollRequest{term=0, candidate=2, lastLogIndex=3982, lastLogTerm=2}: candidate's log is up-to-date
INFO 2023-09-26T11:25:57.887139637Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26}{role=FOLLOWER} - Accepted VoteRequest{term=1, candidate=2, lastLogIndex=3982, lastLogTerm=2}: candidate's log is up-to-date
INFO 2023-09-26T11:25:57.892834402Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26} - Found leader 2
```
See above. `term` is 1, but the lastLogTerm is 2. This is because after restore, raft metastore is empty. So it restarts the term from 1. This is ok so far. But after Zeebe-2 becomes the leader and commits its InitialEntry at index `3983`, Zeebe-0 starts election probably because it did not receive any heartbeat from the leader `Zeebe-2`.

```
INFO 2023-09-26T11:26:01.569385207Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26}{role=FOLLOWER} - Accepted PollRequest{term=1, candidate=0, lastLogIndex=3982, lastLogTerm=2}: candidate's log is up-to-date
INFO 2023-09-26T11:26:01.577404370Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26}{role=FOLLOWER} - Accepted VoteRequest{term=2, candidate=0, lastLogIndex=3982, lastLogTerm=2}: candidate's log is up-to-date
INFO 2023-09-26T11:26:01.582069421Z [jsonPayload.context.partitionId: 26] [resource.labels.podName: zeebe-1] RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-26} - Found leader 0
```
Zeebe-1 accepts poll request from Zeebe-0 because Zeebe-0's lastLogTerm > Zeebe-1's current term 1. This leads to inconsistency. 

**Impact**
If it happens immediately after restore before writing any new data, it should be safe to restart the brokers. Due to the above error, the new leader Zeebe-0 cannot commit anything. So, as a result there won't be any actual data inconsistency. If we wait until all nodes are healthy before restarting the traffic to the cluster, this will not lead to any actual data inconsistency because no user requests has been processed yet. However, if there are new user data that has been processed, then there is a possibility for partial data loss. **Note that the data recovered from the backup won't be lost if this happens. Only new data will be affected.**

**To Reproduce**

Following scenario can lead to this error:
1. A, B, C restored from the same backup, where the term of the last entry in the log is > 1
2. A, B forms the quorum and A became the leader
3. A and B committed new entries 
4. C does not know about the new leader. So it starts new election.

**Expected behavior**

After, restoring from a backup raft can continue working in all scenarios.

**Environment:**
- Zeebe Version: Observed in 8.2.13

Relates to [https://jira.camunda.com/browse/SUPPORT-19174](https://jira.camunda.com/browse/SUPPORT-19174)


 nicpuppa: This affect also a SM customer ([support case](https://jira.camunda.com/browse/SUPPORT-19174)). In this case the problem was with `term`. Since it is reset, no new snapshots can be taken until the term increases to a higher value than the one before the backup. As a result, logs are not compacted and disk usage grows high.

Fixed by this [PR](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/pull/15272)
title: Potential inconsistency in raft after restoring from a backup

gitHubText:
## Description

When we delete a process definition we have a check that looks for any running process instances that belong to the definition. If there is any, the command gets rejected and we don't allow the deletion to happen.

The check doesn't keep in mind that there could be banned instances. As a result, a definition with banned instances is always rejected. What's worse is that the check only happens for the partition which receives the command. As a result the command could be accepted on the receiving partition, but keeps getting rejected on other partition where there may be a banned instance.

## Impact
**Scenario 1**
A user is unable to delete a process definition because there is a banned instance which causes the command to be rejected.

**Scenario 2**
A user deletes a process definition. The command is accepted and distributed. The partition that it gets distributed to has a banned instance. As a result it will never send an acknowledgment. The distributing partition will retry the command distribution indefinitely. This will happen every 5 minutes.
In the meantime users will still be able to start new instances for the process definition. However, this will be flaky as the definition is deleted on some partitions, but not on others. There is a state inconsistency until this bug is resolved.
title: Deleting a process definition only checks running instances and doesn't ignore banned instances

So I will close korthout: Happy to hear that @zxuanhong I'd still like this bug to be fixed at some point, so I'll reopen it. It would be a great issue for any new onboarding team members to get familiar with the FEEL expression vs static expressions concepts. tmetzke: Scope clarification: * This only happens for number values (every other static value is treated as a string already). * This only happens for the assignee attribute (the other user task fields `candidateGroups`, `candidateUsers`, `dueDate`, and `followUpDate` require specific input that is also validated and don't allow plain static number values).

gitHubText:
**Describe the bug** Our [docs state](https://docs.camunda.io/docs/self-managed/zeebe-deployment/zeebe-gateway/interceptors/#loading-an-interceptor-into-a-gateway) that gRPC interceptors are called in the order they are added in the configuration. This is not the case, as the configuration order is not always respected. **To Reproduce** 1. Replace the `containsExactlyInAnyOrder` with `containsExactly` in [this test case](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/gateway/src/test/java/io/camunda/zeebe/gateway/interceptors/impl/InterceptorRepositoryTest.java#L196). 2. Run the test. **Expected behavior** The test passes, as the interceptors are instantiated in the same order as they were added. **Log/Stacktrace**
Full Stacktrace

``` ```

**Environment:** - OS: - Zeebe Version: `8.4.0-SNAPSHOT` - Configuration: koevskinikola: Triage: * Severity is `mid`, as the behavior doesn't impact the correct behavior of Zeebe, but users may experience unexpected behavior if they have interdependent interceptors. * Size is small, as it requires a refactoring of the `IdentityRepository`. koevskinikola: Fixed by https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/pull/15566/commits/95ac625e0102e7c85db590970fb820f6de800c98
title: Interceptor order is not respected

gitHubText:
**Describe the bug**

The constructor of the `ActivateJobsCommandImpl` is trying to set the `workerName` during construction and expects the `config.getDefaultJobWorkerName())` to be non null. This leads to a `NullPointerException` as the underlying builder doesnt support a null value. This is an issue as clients are able to set the `workerName` using the builder pattern after constructing the command.

```
public ActivateJobsCommandImpl(
      final GatewayStub asyncStub,
      final ZeebeClientConfiguration config,
      final JsonMapper jsonMapper,
      final Predicate<Throwable> retryPredicate) {
    this.asyncStub = asyncStub;
    this.jsonMapper = jsonMapper;
    this.retryPredicate = retryPredicate;
    builder = ActivateJobsRequest.newBuilder();
    requestTimeout(config.getDefaultRequestTimeout());
    timeout(config.getDefaultJobTimeout());
    workerName(config.getDefaultJobWorkerName());
  }
```

**To Reproduce**

Create an implementation of the `ZeebeClientProperties` that returns `null` for the `getDefaultJobWorkerName`

**Expected behavior**

The builder should fallback to the default worker name only if it wasnt set by a client when constructing the final command.

**Log/Stacktrace**

```
java.lang.NullPointerException: null
	at io.camunda.zeebe.gateway.protocol.GatewayOuterClass$ActivateJobsRequest$Builder.setWorker(GatewayOuterClass.java:2169)
	at io.camunda.zeebe.client.impl.command.ActivateJobsCommandImpl.workerName(ActivateJobsCommandImpl.java:83)
	at io.camunda.zeebe.client.impl.command.ActivateJobsCommandImpl.<init>(ActivateJobsCommandImpl.java:60)
```

**Environment:**
- Zeebe Version:8.3.0-alpha4

Looks like it happens as the command builder is used instead of the previously used request builder since: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/commit/359a402b5bbee7247749385a458c5b3f3aba7e78

 korthout: @npepinpe This sounds like a regression introduced with #12888. Could you please have a look?
 npepinpe: We had a look together, and AFAIK this is the same behavior as ever. We were always calling `workerName` in the constructor of the command, and it makes sense to me to follow Simon's suggestion and only apply defaults in the build method, not in the constructor.

EDIT: here's the commit which introduced setting the worker name as the default configuration: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/06f4e463efd3ca1be67056660f12abd4ad7867d8/clients/java/src/main/java/io/zeebe/client/impl/job/ActivateJobsCommandImpl.java#L46

That's from 2018, so it looks to me like this was always the behavior. The only thing I can imagine would be that _maybe_ the gRPC behavior changed, where they simply don't allow null values anymore, but I doubt it. I suspect if we check, it was always like this.
 npepinpe: > Looks like it happens as the command builder is used instead of the previously used request builder since: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/commit/359a402b5bbee7247749385a458c5b3f3aba7e78

@sbuettner - can you point out to me where the change from request to command builder happened? From the commit, the code is the same - we extracted an interface out of a class, but the implementation was not changed.

For example, in the "old" implementation:

```java
    final ActivateJobsCommandStep3 activateCommand =
        jobClient
            .newActivateJobsCommand()
            .jobType(jobType)
            .maxJobsToActivate(maxJobsToActivate)
            .timeout(timeout)
            .workerName(workerName);
```

And it was simply moved in the "new" one, but remains the same:

```java
    final ActivateJobsCommandStep3 activateCommand =
        jobClient
            .newActivateJobsCommand()
            .jobType(jobType)
            .maxJobsToActivate(maxJobsToActivate)
            .timeout(timeout)
            .workerName(workerName);
```

I'm also not sure what you mean by request vs command builder :thinking: 
 sbuettner: @npepinpe It looks like it was changed here: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/commit/11c548dd4d46f62119a600da0dc1abad7231c417#diff-7101968ae21254c317a1606e4a1969ec3864b538403541ecc7161351b2bd38ddL86
 npepinpe: Good catch! Seems unrelated to job push, but it is indeed a regression in that sense for 8.3.0. I'll defer to the ZPA team on what the priority for it is.
 korthout: Thanks @npepinpe and @sbuettner for the extra input.

- We'll need to fix this before 8.3 as it regressed recently.
- We consider this mid severity, as a workaround is available (don't set null as the default job worker name)
- We wonder how quickly a user would run into this, do you have to set `null` explicitly, or does it also occur when the client doesn't define any default?
- This would change the impact dramatically, and so our priority
- We want to timebox whether that is the case
- It might be worth it to fix immediately then (but please timebox it)
title: ActivateJobsCommandImpl throws NullPointerException when ZeebeClientProperties.getDefaultJobWorkerName is null

gitHubText:
While testing the impact of pod restarts during dynamic scaling, we observed the following error and partition join was stuck. 
```
java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "io.atomix.raft.storage.system.Configuration.index()" because the return value of "io.atomix.raft.cluster.impl.RaftClusterContext.getConfiguration()" is null
	at io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext.setCommitIndex(RaftContext.java:503) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.appendEntries(PassiveRole.java:588) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.handleAppend(PassiveRole.java:426) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.raft.roles.PassiveRole.onAppend(PassiveRole.java:349) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext.lambda$registerHandlers$19(RaftContext.java:323) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext.lambda$runOnContext$26(RaftContext.java:334) ~[zeebe-atomix-cluster-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at io.atomix.utils.concurrent.SingleThreadContext$WrappedRunnable.run(SingleThreadContext.java:178) ~[zeebe-atomix-utils-8.4.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:8.4.0-SNAPSHOT]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Unknown Source) ~[?:?]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(Unknown Source) ~[?:?]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(Unknown Source) ~[?:?]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(Unknown Source) ~[?:?]
	at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(Unknown Source) ~[?:?]
	at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source) [?:?]
```
Workaround: restart both the leader and the restarted pod.

Initial root cause analysis

- Server B sends join request to the leader
- Leader commits the configuration in the existing members
- Server B receives the configuration, but did not receive the commit information => configuration is kept in memory
- Server B restarts (pod was restarted)
- Server B retries join request => noop because previous join has already completed
- Leader does not sent the configuration again, because Leader assumes Server B already has it. When it sends the Append request, it results in null pointer exception.

This was not a problem before because all servers always started with the static configuration.

Proposed fixes
1. Quick fix: Leader should sent the configuration again when it receives a duplicate join request. Handle null pointer exception in the follower, by simply rejecting the AppendRequest. Eventually the follower should receive the new configuration.
2. Probably a better fix: Include the `configurationIndex` in the `AppendResponse` so that the leader can re-send the configuration if required.
title: NullPointerException when join is retried after a restart

gitHubText:
**Summary** > Try to answer the following as best as possible - How often does the test fail? several times - Does it block your work? It stopped me from merging some changes - Do we suspect that it is a real failure? ðŸ¤· **Failures** > Outline known failure cases, e.g. a failed assertion and its stacktrace obtained from Jenkins
GitHub Error 
The operation was canceled.
**Hypotheses** > List any hypotheses if you have one; can be ommitted **Logs** > If possible, provide more context here, e.g. standard output logs, link to build, etc. [io.camunda.zeebe.it.clustering.dynamic.ScaleResiliencyTest$ScaleDown-1-output.txt](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/files/13451838/io.camunda.zeebe.it.clustering.dynamic.ScaleResiliencyTest.ScaleDown-1-output.txt) **Additional** I was able to find out which test was still running thanks to @deepthidevaki's awesome script: ```sh grep "Running io." test.out > running.out grep "Tests run:.*" test.out | grep "io." > testsRan.out cut -d' ' -f3 running.out > testsRunning.out cut -d'-' -f3 testsRan.out | cut -d' ' -f3 > testsRanClasses.out grep -vf testsRanClasses.out testsRunning.out ``` deepthidevaki: Observations from the log: Broker-2 has attempted to leave partition 2, but could not succeed because Broker-1 is not available. But it has already committed that first part of the joint consensus. When Broker-1 is restarted, in some cases partition 2 in Broker-2 is not yet started. In this case, Broker-0 which is the leader might commit the second part of joint consensus before Broker-2 is ready. When this happens, Broker-2 waits forever to become partition-2 to be ready. ``` 15:02:25.031 [Broker-0] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-0-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.roles.CandidateRole - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2}{role=CANDIDATE} - Cancelling election 15:02:25.032 [Broker-0] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-0-2] INFO io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Found leader 0 15:02:25.032 [Broker-0] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-0-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.roles.LeaderAppender - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Configuring 2 15:02:25.032 [Broker-0] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-0-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.roles.LeaderAppender - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Configuring 1 15:02:25.034 [Broker-2] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-2-2] INFO io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Found leader 0 ``` Here leader is configuring both 1 and 2 with the first part of joint consensus which was already committed before the restart of broker-2. ``` 15:02:25.035 [Broker-1] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-1-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.roles.FollowerRole - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2}{role=FOLLOWER} - Rejected InternalAppendRequest[term=3, leader=0, prevLogIndex=5, prevLogTerm=2, commitIndex=4, entries=[]]: Previous index (5) is greater than the local log's last index (3) 15:02:25.035 [Broker-0] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-0-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.roles.LeaderAppender - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Configuring 1 ``` Here, Broker-0 configures Broker 1 with second part of joint consensus where Broker-2 is not part of the configuration anymore. ``` 15:02:25.037 [Broker-1] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-1-2] INFO io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Setting firstCommitIndex to 4. RaftServer is ready only after it has committed events upto this index 15:02:25.037 [Broker-1] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-1-2] INFO io.atomix.raft.impl.RaftContext - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Commit index is 4. RaftServer is ready 15:02:25.037 [Broker-1] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-1-2] DEBUG io.atomix.raft.impl.DefaultRaftServer - RaftServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Server started successfully! 15:02:25.037 [Broker-1] [raft-server-2] [raft-server-1-2] INFO io.atomix.raft.partition.impl.RaftPartitionServer - RaftPartitionServer{raft-partition-partition-2} - Server successfully bootstrapped partition PartitionId{id=2, group=raft-partition} in 4096ms ``` Broker-2 has already left the configuration, So it never becomes READY. As a result `startFuture` in Partition's StartupProcess is never completed. ``` 15:02:32.091 [Broker-2] [Startup] [zb-actors-0] INFO io.camunda.zeebe.broker.partitioning.PartitionManagerImpl - Leaving partition 2 15:02:32.094 [Broker-2] [Startup] [zb-actors-1] DEBUG io.camunda.zeebe.broker.partitioning.Partition - Shutdown was called with context: PartitionStartupContext{partition=2} ``` Leave completes successfully, as it has already left the configuration. So it tries to shutdown. But [shutdown is blocked because it is waiting on the `startupFuture`](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/b10310596bc38b644d062786efca505d8c51c8fd/scheduler/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/scheduler/startup/StartupProcess.java#L198). ``` 15:04:20.968 [Broker-2] [Startup] [zb-actors-0] DEBUG io.camunda.zeebe.broker.partitioning.Partition - Shutdown was called with context: PartitionStartupContext{partition=2} 15:04:20.968 [Broker-2] [Startup] [zb-actors-0] INFO io.camunda.zeebe.broker.partitioning.Partition - Shutdown already in progress ``` After the test fails, when it tries to shutdown the broker, we see that the shutdown of partition 2 is already in progress. Test is stuck waiting in the shutdown leading to the timeout of CI job. The test passes when Broker-2 becomes ready before Broker-1 is up.
title: IT timeout due to `ScaleResiliencyTest.ScaleDown`

gitHubText:
This could cause problem in `replay` mode, Form events will be missed and not added to the state.

 korthout: I've quickly verified the issue, and this can lead to the loss of the deployed Forms on 8.3 and 8.4.0-alpha1.

In that case, existing jobs of User Tasks may still be referring to the key of that form, but it no longer exists in Zeebe. 

When instances activate User Task with form id set after the replay missed the Form events, an Incident is raised at the User Task:
```
E PI       ACTIVATING     - #34->#21 K14 - USER_TASK "task" in <process "PROCESS"[K10]>
E INCIDENT CREATED        - #35->#21 K15 - FORM_NOT_FOUND Expected to find a form with id 'Form_0w7r08e', but no form with this id is found, at least a form with this id should be available. To resolve the Incident please deploy a form with the same id,  @"task"[K14] in <process "PROCESS"[K10]>
```
 korthout: In short: **The impact is a potential loss of deployed form**. 

When that happens, the user will notice because newly activated User Tasks will raise an Incident that the Form cannot be found.

User must redeploy the form to fix the problem, but the bug can re-occur afterward until we have a fix.
 korthout: Marking it as sev high because users can recover easily. Loss of data is very limited. And chance of occurrence is low. A fix is on the way though.
title: Form events are not replayed

gitHubText:
If we allow the migration of process instances not entirely in a wait state, Zeebe would wrongly execute the process instance after the migration.

In short, unprocessed commands referring to the source process definition may exist on the log stream with a position higher than the process instance migration command. When we process these commands, the engine wrongly attempts to continue the processing on the source process definition as if the migration didn't occur. For a complete discussion, please read 'How should we deal with process instances in non-wait states?' in the epic's 'Discussions and Decisions' section. 

We can either:
1. Reject process instance migration if we know the process instance is not entirely in a wait state.
2. Don't trust the process definition key in such commands, but rather look up the process definition from the state when processing commands.

A downside to option 1 is: We don't know what commands exist on the log with a higher position than the command being processed. It may be that this solution is not water tight, requiring us to investigate option 2.

A downside to option 2 is: Some commands may refer to elements that no longer exist in the target process. These will be rejected.

 korthout: Labeling this as a bug because it is if we don't resolve this.
 korthout: Estimated as medium, because it's not entirely clear how to resolve this yet. Estimate might be lower when this becomes clear.
 korthout: TL;DR: **I want to focus on option 2 for two reasons**:
- **it should be a design requirement for any command processor in the first place**. By applying this requirement to all command processors, we simplify reasoning about the system and bring consistency to implementation. This requirement should be documented in our developer documentation.
- **it is less restrictive than option 1**, allowing for migrations of process instances in active execution rather than only those in a complete wait state.

---

Let's consider the different options.

1. Reject process instance migration if we know the process instance is not entirely in a wait state.

This raises the question: Can we detect that the process instance is currently not entirely in a wait state? 

Let's start with regular process instance execution over sequence flows. Each flow scope element instance keeps track of the number of sequence flows that are currently taken inside it for which the target element has not yet been activated. So, we can use this. 

If the sequence flow has not yet been taken, an element instance is always active (i.e. activating, activated, completing, or terminating). 

This is the case irrespective of unprocessed `ProcessInstance` and `ProcessInstanceBatch` commands on the log.

However, other unprocessed commands referring to the process definition on the log may continue the process execution. This means that option 1 is restrictive, and that option 1 is not water tight. This leads us to consider option 2: 

2. Don't trust the process definition key in such commands, but rather look up the process definition from the state when processing commands.

Option 2 is actually a requirement for any command in our system because of the async nature of Zeebe's engine. Typically, the state is different when the command is appended to the log than when it is processed because other commands may been executed in between. Therefore, we can never trust all data in commands. This rule follows naturally from our stream processing design, and is why we've build things like [ProcessInstanceStateTransitionGuard](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/main/engine/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/engine/processing/bpmn/ProcessInstanceStateTransitionGuard.java).

Commands that refer to data that may have changed due to migration are:
- `Timer:TRIGGER` refers to `targetElementId` and `processDefinitionKey` 
- `ProcessMessageSubscription:CORRELATE` refers to `bpmnProcessId` and `elementId`
- ~~`Signal:BROADCAST`~~ does not refer to properties that may have changed due to migration
- `Incident:Resolve` refers to `bpmnProcessId`, `processDefinitionKey`, and `elementId`
- `Job:*` (multiple intents) refers to `bpmnProcessId`, `processDefinitionVersion`, `processDefinitionKey`, and `elementId`
- `UserTask:*` (multiple intents) refers to `bpmnProcessId`, `processDefinitionVersion`, `processDefinitionKey`, and `elementId`

In addition, the following commands also continue the process execution but could be covered by rejection of the command (option 1) if we follow that approach:
- `ProcessInstance:*` (multiple intents) refers to `bpmnProcessId`, `elementId`, `version`, and `processDefinitionKey`
- `ProcessInstanceBatch:*` (multiple intents)

Lastly, some commands don't directly continue the process execution but still refer to data that may have changed:
- `MessageSubscription:*` (multiple intents) refers to `bpmnProcessId`

So, option
 korthout: The number of affected commands is strongly reduced for the first iteration due to the supported scope of instance migration MVP.

However, in later iterations. These problems may surface when more is supported.
 korthout: Quick dump of my latest spike: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/compare/korthout-15129-unprocessed-commands-with-outdated-data-due-to-migration
 romansmirnov: @korthout and @saig0 ,

a potential option: Would it be possible to bookmark that a current "active path" (aka element instance or similar) has an outstanding follow-up command (to bring that in a valid - or wait - state)? While migrating an active path, the processor could check for this bookmark/flag being set or not. And if there is an outstanding command, it stops migrating, rolls back, and rejects the migration command.

Or the instance itself could bookkeeping all outstanding commands? So they are all in one place stored, and once a command is being executed it is removed from that.

Details would need to be defined, but would this resolve the issue? If not, what is missing?
 korthout: @romansmirnov Sorry I did not find the time to answer anymore before my FTO. I believe @saig0 will consider your proposal.

@saig0 If you manage to resolve this bug, please notify @berkaycanbc that we can remove the `@ExperimentalAPI` annotation from the java-client **and** the danger banner in the [concept docs](https://github.com/camunda/camunda-docs/pull/3000#issuecomment-1847526591)
 saig0: @romansmirnov I will follow your idea. :+1:  

The required data about the active "outstanding" command should be available already. I will check the data in the migration processor to reject the migration command.
title: Avoid executing process according to unprocessed commands referring to source process definition

gitHubText:
**Describe the bug**

This error happened on Sat 03/11:

```
"StreamProcessor-1 failed, marking it as dead: StreamProcessor-1{status=DEAD, issue=HealthIssue[message=null, throwable=io.camunda.zeebe.util.exception.UnrecoverableException: Authorization data unavailable: The Token can't be used before 2023-11-03T14:46:52Z., cause=null]}"
```

You can find the logs [here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1wJqLwgla0px44joF49Ve0bnW0WzZvtQC)


 megglos: ZDP-Triage:
- JWT token validation must relates to multi-tenancy, would delegate this to ZPA
 korthout: ZPA triage:
- marking it as high severity because it caused a DEAD partition
- we should investigate and fix it soon
- might make sense to work on this while multi-tenancy is fresh

@koevskinikola I heard that you may already have some thoughts about this issue. Could you share them in a comment?
 koevskinikola: Related to a [SUPPORT case](https://jira.camunda.com/browse/SUPPORT-19112) as well.
 koevskinikola: My hypothesis is that this is a time zone issue.

1. We're using `Instance.now()` to set the `JWT#issuedAt` (`iat`) claim [here](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/blob/6a730a7bf57f0491cb0b29e5b2c90533330b6c1b/auth/src/main/java/io/camunda/zeebe/auth/impl/JwtAuthorizationEncoder.java#L66).
2. The `Instance.now()` method provides an `Instant` from the system UTC clock.
3. If the cluster is set on a different time zone, the JWT validation might throw an exception that `The Token can't be used before xxx`.

I will try to confirm this with a test.

Proposed solutions:
1. We use the `ActorClock` to set the time instead.
2. We remove the `JWT.issuedAt` (`iat`) claim
3. We remove the JWT validation when decoding the JWT token.

Decision:
We will implement proposals 2 and 3 from above because:
* We're only using the JWT token for data transport. The JWT token is not signed, and not used outside of Zeebe, so any data other than the authorization data isn't relevant. That means that the `issuedAt` claim can be removed.
* Since the token isn't signed, validation isn't required. Coupled with the bad `issuedAt` implementation, it is causing bugs. It is better to disable the validation since existing Zeebe installations may already face the problem, and we want to disable the validation so that the issue doesn't pop up for existing JWT tokens.
   * In that case, we will need to do our own validation that the `authorized_tenants` JWT claim is present. This can be done by doing a null-check when fetching the claim data since if the claim is not present, a `null` is returned.

cc @korthout 

 romansmirnov: @koevskinikola, just trying to understand the root cause of the issue, have you been able to validate your hypothesis? Isn't this "just" a clock syncing problem between the gateway node and broker node? By setting a leeway when verifying the token, would it help mitigate the issue?

However, please consider this just a question to get a better understanding of the root cause. Meaning, I agree with the decision above to solve the problem anyway ðŸ˜„ 
 koevskinikola: Hey @romansmirnov ,

I think you're right. It doesn't seem to be time-zone related, but just a matter of leeway.

That's because:
1. The JWT library that we use (`java-jwt`) also uses `Instant.now()` inside the `Verifier` to get the current time to compare against.
    * Since we're also using `Instant.now()` to set the `issuedAt` claim, this means the Verifier is always comparing UTC times.
2. The `defaultLeeway` value in `java-jwt` is set to `0`. This means that verifying this token even half a second earlier will cause an issue (this seems to be the case in one of the occurences).

So we can definitely adjust the `leeway` to compensate. However, as I pointed out, we're not really signing the JWT token, so the `issuedAt` claim is irrelevant here.

I would feel more confident in not verifying the `issuedAt` claim at all right now. If we ever decide to expose the JWT data to exported events, we can:
1. Sign it first.
2. Set and adjust the verification for the best-practice claims (like the `issuedAt`)

UPDATE:
I confirmed my hypothesis by:
1. Providing a fixed clock with which I set the `issuedAt` claim on a JWT token.
2. Create a JWT Verifier on which I set a fixed clock 1 second behing.

The result is that the JWT verification fails with the same message `The Token can't be used before...`/
 Zelldon: Happened in 8.4.0-alpha1 https://console.cloud.google.com/errors/detail/CI_Y0MHF3fmnggE;service=zeebe;time=P7D?project=zeebe-io but I suspect this fix was not part of the release.
 korthout: Nope 0d600f736e6c1c6cc69cda38d40c78dc4d5abfea is not part of `8.4.0-alpha1`.
title: 8.3.x release benchmark - Authorization data unavailable: The Token can't be used before xxx

gitHubText:
**Describe the bug**

While this is not always the case, in CW44 (and new benchmarks), I've seen that some nodes sometimes end up doing up to 8000 IOPS, instead of the ~4000 from the previous benchmarks. 

Note that some nodes still do 4000, and this issue is intermittent. But it's unclear in our benchmarks why one node would do so much more IOPS. Leadership is well balanced, each partition is doing ~50 PI/s, the journal append rate is similar, the leader commit rate is similar, etc.

Yet somehow, one or more nodes is doing _way_ more I/O than the others.

**Log/Stacktrace**

Here's CW43 when one node is leader for 2 partitions:

![image](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/43373/0e2450e1-747d-44f2-89fd-fbe9232c943a)

Here's CW43 when leadership is well balanced:

![image](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/43373/446f502a-9dc8-4afc-90ce-8c0127d6d04d)

Now, it's still weird that one node is doing way less I/O than the others, but we're still at the 4000 mark.

Here's CW44 with leadership well balanced: 

![image](https://github.com/camunda/zeebe/assets/43373/1f6d1c99-cf5c-4279-afd1-1317b6466ac3)


 Zelldon: Triage:

We should take a look asap and asses the current state/issue.
 npepinpe: Timebox root causing in the next 2 weeks. First check CW45, if doesn't happen then we can consider it a fluke and close. Otherwise root cause, and put it back into planning to discuss priority on the fix.
